She is a board member of the North Carolina Principals and Assistant Principals Association and was named the Northwestern Regional Principal of the Year in 2018.

Earlier today, Governor Cooper announced that all North Carolina public schools will remain closed through May 15. Please know that we have been preparing for such a scenario. After Spring Break, we will extend our remote learning initiative. Starting Monday, students will continue with the packets assigned last week. Schools will use next week to finish up plans to cover new material moving forward and communicate these with families.

The "grab and go" lunch numbers continue to increase with 2536 meals served today. We would love to see more families take advantage of this resource, so please go to the nearest elementary school on weekdays from 11AM to 1PM and pick up food for anyone 18 or under.

Let's all do our part to avoid traveling and grouping up to help limit the spread of this virus. Please keep all essential workers in your thoughts as they serve our community.

Together, we will get through this.

We will share more information in the coming days, so please stay tuned.

Have a great Spring Break!

Thank you and have a great night.

Due to the continuing weather, flooding, and road situation; McDowell County Schools will be closed for students and all staff on Wednesday, May 30. McDowell County is currently under a state of emergency; and Emergency Management is reporting numerous issues across the county in the form of flooding, slides, downed trees, and unsafe roads. Evacuations are still taking place for residents in the Catawba River areas below the Lake Tahoma dam until state officials can properly examine once daylight breaks. DOT is reportedly now out of road closure signs due to the number of areas affected, so please be careful if you must venture out. Shelters have been opened at the YMCA in Marion and the First Baptist Church in Old Fort. Call 652-3241 for more information about shelters. Thankfully, there have been no injuries or deaths thus far. Let us all do our part to help the emergency services personnel by staying off the roadways and allow them to focus on our neighbors who need them the most right now. Be careful and stay safe.

Thank you.

Earlier this evening, the McDowell County Sheriff's Office was contacted about a potential threat posted to Facebook that made reference to BV and Marion schools. Their investigation determined the schools in question to be Buckeye Valley High School and Marion Schools in Delaware County, Ohio. The Sheriff's Office has been in communication with the authorities in Ohio currently investigating the case and were able to confirm it has nothing to do with Marion, McDowell County or any of the McDowell County Schools. I want to publicly thank Sheriff Greene and the McDowell County Sheriff's Office for their assistance with this matter and continued partnership with McDowell County Schools.

Know that we take safety very seriously and encourage people to contact us with information regarding any potential dangers or threats. If you see or hear something, please say something. We need your help to remain proactive.

Thank you for your attention to this message and have a great evening.

post_text: Overnight a band of precipitation occurred which has led to slick conditions in certain parts of the county and specifically in the City of Marion. Emergency services personnel are reporting black ice and a light coating of snow on some roads. As a result McDowell County Schools will operate on a two-hour delay for students and staff Wednesday, March 15. This will allow crews to treat the roads and give drivers greater visibility to spot potential trouble areas during the morning commute. We will continue to monitor road conditions in case we have to make another schedule adjustment.
